data.title: Propossal For Additional Functionality in SpriteBatch.DrawString
data.body:
Three proposed additions which i feel belong in mono-game as a part of it.
rather then as extensions or helper class's. With arguments as to why below them.

1) A overload that takes a starting and ending character position, for the DrawString method specifically the one that takes a StringBuilder.

2) GetMaxFontCharacterLineHeight ( with a scaling parameter as well)
   (this would relate to a character with the largest pixel height in a spritefont
    im unsure and its not clear that a measure string will return this )

3) Couple overloads for MeasureString that allows you to pass a scaling factor 
    and or specify a part of a stringbuilder to measure.

**why**

This should be there because when drawing scaled text. 
You cannot measure properly, the scaled text you will be drawing with a Drawstring call...
That makes use of the scaling parameter.
At least not without basically re-doing everything mono-game just did ...yourself.

Even the basic recalculation of the pixel width height from a scaling requires a few steps. That is very hard for a new person to figure out. 
It is also inefficient and difficult to do so effectively from outside the inner-working's of mono game itself. Which basically goe's thru all the required steps anyways, in Spritefont and Spritebatch.
So i think it should be part of the inner workings of mono-game in either case.

_i was going to petition shawn hargraves about this for xna 5 but you know how that goes.._

To add to this i will offer some scenario's, general and specific towards the implementation bonus's.

**possible scenario's case's that could then easily be created by programers using mono game**

Text That need not have a new or altered string or StringBuilder Instance for a drawn effect like scrolling and is efficient 
(strings resizing operations being one of the worst gc collection case senario's)
Rescaling text to fit a rectangular area.
Text rectangles drawn over image rectangles, (user made buttons with effects)
Text that scrolls up down as well as left right (though it maybe more work). 
Delimiting text to user designated text area's such as scalable text boxes, chat boxes ect.
Measurement of text for proportional screen scaling, 
independent of the screen resolution i.e.  ...
(text could be made to maintain proportion to a percentage of the screen under virtual coordinates if so desired)

**possible scenarios for extension's or extra's using the above**

The user wishes to create a overloaded drawstring, that takes a rectangle instead of a vector2 
The rectangle will delimit the text so that the text will not draw characters that will exceed the width and height in pixels of the rectangle area.

the user wishes to have data in a small box when he move's his mouse over it ,... it expands to the full text this can then be done by simply using one drawstring call or the other and a collision box

im sure their are more. these are only some i have considered.
i can elaborate on the steps if desired

data.title: MGCB .dds File support
data.body: At the moment, .dds files appear to be unsupported by the MGCB tool.

data.title: Ensure foreground context is current on the main thread
data.body:
Background must be non-current, otherwise it will raise error 170 (resource is in use) on the next MakeCurrent() call.

Fixes issue #2474

data.title: PipelineTool import fixes
data.body:
Fixed 'content include' build actions being skipped (assumed everything was a 'compile include').
Fixed includes for 'copy only don't build' items being skipped.

data.title: PipelineTool: File > Save should ask before overwriting a file if that file is not the currently openproject
data.body: This probably only occurs when importing a project and hitting save, when there was a previous project already there.

data.title: Threaded context issue
data.body: I have a threaded background loader that used to work until recently. I'm now receiving a   "Failed to make context 131072 current. Error: 170" that appears to originate from "BlockOnUIThread" specifically in the Windows || linux || angle def section lock on the "BackgroundContext.MakeCurrent(WindowInfo)" call. I'm using the WindowsGL build and my background loader code can be found here: https://github.com/NetGnome/Vaerydian/blob/master/Vaerydian/Screens/NewLoadingScreen.cs

data.title: MGFX ColorWriteEnable
data.body:
This adds support for the ColorWriteEnable render state to MGFX.

Resolves #1356.

data.title: MGFX Parser Improvements
data.body:
This PR moves all the interpreting of render and sampler states directly into the generation of the parser tree and out of the parse evaluator.  This gives us better error messages with line numbers whenever an unknown state is encountered.

I also fixed the sampler state parsing to properly support DX10 style sampler declarations.

data.title: Make Lidgren.Network.Windows target .net 4 like MonoGame
data.body: Fixes #2305

data.title: DrawInstancedPrimitives
data.body:
Hi, I'm porting my game engine from XNA to to MonoGame, and the game it is intended for absolutely cannot go without instancing at all, as the entire game is built primarily with that draw routine in mind. 

 I'm kind of stuck at a fork in the road atm: 
- one way says to go back to XNA to avoid rewiring my entire geometry batcher ( and all of my shaders )
- the otherway says " downsize and redo everything ".
  
  So for some ( like me ), my options aren't looking so great.
  
  I'm actually kind of amazed that this isn't implemented at all yet, even on the Windows DirectX builds of monogame.

Minor patch to resolve that

data.title: Fallback to the maximum multisampling level if the level is too high
data.body:
This ensures that the specified multi-sampling level is supported before it is used by the device.  Without this check, it's impossible to request multi-sampling levels safely, since a level that is too high will cause an exception to be thrown.

This means you can now specify "32" for the multi-sampling level, and it will automatically fall back to the highest supported version on the device.

I'm not too sure about `Format.R32G32B32A32_Typeless` though.  I couldn't find an API to get the current format of the graphics device, although I'm sure it'll exist somewhere and this code should probably use the result of that instead.

data.title: Mouse input on destkop platforms
data.body:
I'm opening this issue to track the status of the `Mouse` implementation in MonoGame.

According to the XNA documentation and my own observations (please correct any mistakes):
1. `Mouse.GetState()` reports the absolute coordinates of the desktop cursor, with the origin set to the window specified by `Mouse.WindowHandle`. A cursor left or above the window has negative coordinates.
2. Mouse coordinates are reported in integer pixels. The resolution of the mouse is limited by the resolution of the monitor (typically 96dpi.)
3. Pointer ballistics are always applied. There is no option to disable mouse acceleration. 
4. The mouse is not restricted to the `GameWindow`. Users can freely move the cursor outside the window and focus different applications. The state of the cursor can be queried even if the `GameWindow` does not have focus.
5. The mouse is restricted by the desktop rectangle. Once the mouse reaches a desktop edge, it will no longer report movement in that direction. Infinite (relative) motion can only be achieved by calling `Mouse.SetPosition` to reset the mouse position.
6. By default, the mouse cursor is invisible inside the `GameWindow`. This can be changed by setting `Game.IsCursorVisible` to true. Using a custom mouse cursor is _not_ supported.
7. `Mouse.SetPosition` does not appear to move the actual cursor, only change its logical position. If the `GameWindow` has focus, `SetPosition` works everywhere on screen. Otherwise, it only works if the cursor lies within the `GameWindow` bounds.

Judging from the above, it appears that `Mouse.GetState` is a thin wrapper around the `GetCursorPos` Windows API. I must admit I find this somewhat surprising, as points 2 and 3 are usually considered a deal-breaker for specific kinds of games, notably first-person shooters.

Point 3 has the additional disadvantage that pointer ballistics differ significantly between operating systems. A mouse control scheme tuned to work on Windows will feel awkward on Mac OS X and vice versa.

Edit: users can set `Mouse.WindowHandle` to a different window in order to change the origin of the coordinate system. It is unlikely that this can be implemented in a cross-platform fashion, so I am ignoring this property in my tests.

data.title: (RFC) Add a progress bar to asset reloading
data.body:
Hi!

reloading assets can take a lot of time on some android devices, so to avoid the user thinking that the reloading screen is frozen, I tried to add a progress bar.

However I'm not good at following other people's style and my API design knowledge stinks :) Here is my approach:

http://pastebin.com/Kzy48Aqr

first two blocks are new code, and ReloadGraphicAssets is slightly modified to set and increment the variables.

Any suggestions? Should I return an struct instead of two "out" variables? Is this the correct place to put this? Maybe this information should be sent to the Resumer (but adding parameters to the Draw function would break compatibility).

Thanks!
Kak

data.title: Doc Fixes
data.body:
A few fixes from the documentation work:
- We accidentally were scanning WindowsGL for Win8 docs.
- Fixed a bunch of cases of internal classes being public appearing in the docs.
- Fixed some doc warnings.
- Fixed incorrect parameter in `Cue.GetVariable()`.
- Made it so that the content pipeline assembly can access internal helper methods in framework.

data.title: Remove Virtual GamePad Implementations
data.body:
This is the outcome of https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2367.

We need to remove all our virtual gamepad implementations for mobile devices:
- Most of them are incomplete or broken in some way.
- They are mostly not customizable.
- Most developers will implement their own tuned to their specific games needs.

It would be better to remove these from the code base and instead transplant the code to the samples projects where they can be of use to people.

While we're at it be sure to delete [ButtonDefinition.cs](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Input/ButtonDefinition.cs).

data.title: Building MonoGame.WindowsPhone from source in VS 2013 ends with error
data.body:
Hi,

I have been trying to build MonoGame.WindowsPhone in VS 2013. The build always ends with the following error: 

Error   3   Member 'Microsoft.Xna.Framework.DisplayOrientation.Default' cannot be accessed with an instance reference; qualify it with a type name instead  E:\MonoGame\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Graphics\PresentationParameters.cs  211 34  MonoGame.Framework.WindowsPhone

Thanks a lot,
Christian

data.title: Support Texture Filter None
data.body: This adds MGFX support for texture filter "None" which can be used to disable mipmapping on platforms that implement `MipMapLevelOfDetailBias`.

data.title: PipelineTool, Import XNA project
data.body:
Can now import an XNA .contentproj using File > Import.
- Microsoft assemblies referenced by the contentproj are ignored.
- MonoGameContentProcessors assembly referenced by the contentproj are ignored.
- Processors / Importers which could not be found will appear as "Invalid / Missing" in the property grid.
- Editing the project references will trigger a reevaluation of all importers / processors to locate 'missing' ones.

If your game was previously using MonoGameContentProcessors.dll, all those processors are now defined in Monogame.Framework.Pipeline.dll (which does not need to be explicitly added as a reference). PipelineTool will automatically remap to the new name for certain processors (such as MGTextureProcessor -> TextureProcessor).

Note that your game's pipeline assembly which contains custom processor/importers must be built against Monogame.Framework.Pipeline (and not just that but the same version of it that the PipelineTool is built against) or the PipelineTool will fail to extract its Processor / Importer types.

data.title: Audio Docs
data.body:
First run at some documentation for classes in the Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio namespace.

I also took care of replacing the old licenses while I was at it.

A contribution to https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2378

data.title: Mouse.GetState does not obtain correct values with multiple button presses
data.body:
Using the 3.2 release and MonoGame Windows project.

Using Mouse.GetState when multiple mouse buttons are being pressed does not return correct values. It seems to report only the latest button being pressed instead of both.

Example- (mouse position must stay the same):
Mouse.GetState when mouse.RightButton is pressed: Works as intended.
Mouse.GetState when both mouse.RightButton THEN mouse.LeftButton are pressed: Only reports mouse.LeftButton as being pressed.

(I have a code sample that demonstrates the issue if needed.)

This occurs when no other action is subsequently performed on the mouse. For example, if the mouse position changes when both buttons are pressed, it will update and work as intended. This issue DOES NOT occur using a Windows OpenGL project.

New to issue tracking, sorry for any mistakes :/
